quotes.quote: Matthew Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 1 centers on Hannah's profound spiritual struggle and response to divine provision. Focusing on her barrenness amidst family tension, Henry emphasizes how Hannah's silent, tearful prayer at Shiloh—unheard by Eli yet deeply attuned to God—reveals the power of heartfelt devotion over words. Theologically, this narrative illustrates God's sovereign care for the marginalized and broken, particularly those whose spiritual needs are silenced by circumstances. Hannah's vow to dedicate her child to the Lord foreshadows Christ's own unique dedication: just as Hannah's barren womb became the vessel for Samuel, Christ's "no woman gave birth" paradox (John 1:13) fulfills God's promise to the broken. Henry highlights that true prayer transcends verbal expression, embracing the inner anguish of the soul, while Hannah's humility in accepting God's timing—delaying her son's presentation until weaned—demonstrates trust in divine providence. Practically, this story urges believers to navigate grief without retaliating (as Hannah avoided blaming Eli's sons), to pray with vulnerable honesty even when unheard, and to dedicate children to God early, recognizing that spiritual formation begins in the home. Crucially, Hannah's story points to Christ: her vow to "give him to the LORD" echoes the sacrifice of the Son who became the ultimate offering for sin, showing that God's grace transforms barrenness into purpose. For modern readers, it teaches that when emotional burdens overwhelm, we must seek God's face without judgment, knowing His promise to answer prayers—especially for the spiritually barren—through the ultimate gift of His Son. (248 words)

Calvin's commentary on 1 Samuel 1 emphasizes Hannah's profound spiritual struggle as a model for believers facing divine silence. He highlights how Hannah's barrenness, a condition of profound human weakness, becomes the very context for God's sovereign intervention. Calvin notes that Hannah's silent prayer (1 Samuel 1:13) reveals the depth of faith that transcends words—her sorrowful spirit speaking directly to the Lord without vocalization. This act of vulnerable submission, coupled with her vow to dedicate her child to God's service, demonstrates that true consecration arises from recognizing God's ultimate authority over life circumstances, not human effort. Theologically, Calvin underscores that God's response to Hannah's prayer (the birth of Samuel) reveals His faithfulness to those who persist in prayer despite apparent divine abandonment, affirming that God's promises are rooted in His character, not human merit. Practically, this passage encourages believers to cultivate persistent, heartfelt prayer in times of spiritual barrenness, trusting God's timing even when circumstances seem hopeless. Crucially, Calvin draws Christological connections: Hannah's vow to dedicate her child to the Lord prefigures Christ as the ultimate "man child" who would be given to God's service—both in the sense of His sacrificial obedience and the fulfillment of God's covenant promises. Her commitment to Samuel's lifelong consecration mirrors Christ's own submission to the Father's will, demonstrating that true worship requires surrendering one's life to God's purpose, even when the path is unseen. This narrative thus challenges believers to seek God's presence with humility and trust, recognizing that Christ's work is the ultimate answer to human barrenness. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 1 illuminates Hannah's profound spiritual struggle and divine response through meticulous contextual analysis. Elkanah, an Ephrathite Levite, annually traveled to Shiloh with his two wives—Peninnah, who had children, and Hannah, barren—demonstrating the cultural norm of multiple wives while highlighting Hannah's deep emotional distress. Her yearning for a child, exacerbated by Peninnah's jealousy, led Hannah to weep in Shiloh's temple courtyard, where she made a specific vow: if God would grant her a son, she would dedicate him to lifelong service as a Nazirite. Poole emphasizes that this vow transcends mere ritual, reflecting Hannah's intimate covenant with God amid spiritual barrenness—a condition many believers face when God seems silent. Theologically, Hannah's story reveals God's responsiveness to raw, persistent prayer, especially when human effort has failed. Her vow foreshadows Christ, the ultimate Nazirite, who was consecrated to God's purpose without sin, his head untouched by the razor—a symbol of divine sanctification. Practically, this narrative urges believers to embrace persistent, specific prayer when circumstances feel barren, trusting God's faithfulness beyond immediate results. It also teaches that vows, when rooted in humility and obedience, become sacred commitments that align our lives with God's redemptive plan. Hannah's journey—from grief to vowed obedience—serves as a timeless model for overcoming spiritual desolation while pointing to Christ, who fulfills the promise of a Savior born of divine grace, not human effort. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that 1 Samuel chapter 1 presents Hannah's story as a profound theological bridge between Israel's judicial era and the Messianic kingdom, highlighting how her barrenness—despite her fervent prayer and sacrifice—becomes a typological image of the Church's spiritual struggles. Theologically, Hannah's song (1 Samuel 2:1–10) foreshadows Christ's reign by celebrating God's sovereignty over human limitations, directly linking Samuel's birth to the promise of the anointed One. Barnes stresses that Samuel's role as the transitional figure between judges and kings (as outlined in the broader narrative) underscores his function as a forerunner of Christ, whose anointing (1 Samuel 2:10) is the fulfillment of the covenant. Practically, Hannah's response to her anguish—praying persistently while sacrificing her desire for children—offers a model for believers facing spiritual barrenness: surrendering needs to God with faith that transcends immediate outcomes, trusting His timing and provision. This narrative reveals that true spiritual vitality arises not from human achievement but from surrender to God's purpose, as Hannah's quiet confidence in divine sovereignty enabled her to become the mother of the prophet who would eventually point to the Messiah. Ultimately, Barnes connects Hannah's story to Christ's identity as both the "anointed" (Messiah) and the "son of David," illustrating how the Old Testament's transitions toward the kingdom of God were prefigured in the lives of those who laid the foundation for Christ's reign—urging modern believers to cultivate persistent prayer and sacrificial trust in the same God who answered Hannah's plea. (248 words)

Henry observes that Hannah's prayer in 1 Samuel 2 reveals profound theological insights: her joy stems not in Samuel but in God's salvific power, emphasizing that true prosperity comes from recognizing the Lord's sovereignty over all circumstances—whether in poverty or abundance. God's justice actively reverses worldly status, lifting the humble and crushing the arrogant, while His sovereignty ensures the righteous are protected and the wicked are silenced. Crucially, Henry highlights that this chapter foreshadows Christ as the true Messiah, the "anointed" whose kingdom brings salvation and reverses human power structures. The narrative's contrast between Eli's neglect of his sons' wickedness and Samuel's faithful service underscores the danger of failing to discipline children in godly ways, while also pointing to Christ as the perfect High Priest who replaces the Levitical order. Practically, this calls believers to embrace God's grace in their current circumstances, resist pride, and actively cultivate humility—knowing that God uses the seemingly weak to accomplish His purposes. It also urges parents to vigilantly nurture spiritual discipline in children, avoiding the pitfalls of Eli's failure. Theophatically, Hannah's prayer and Samuel's calling reveal that Christ's kingdom operates through divine reversal: the poor are exalted, the mighty are humbled, and the anointed One (Christ) ultimately establishes a new covenant where God's people find security and purpose. This commentary thus bridges the Old Testament's promise of God's active care with the New Testament reality of Christ's ongoing reign. (248 words)

Calvin observed that Hannah's prayer in 1 Samuel 2 reveals God's sovereign authority and justice, contrasting divine holiness with human arrogance. He emphasized that God alone is the true rock and source of salvation, actively reversing societal inequalities—lifting the poor and humbling the powerful—while affirming His ultimate control over life and death. Calvin connected this to the profound theological insight that God's justice operates through His providence, ensuring that the wicked are silenced and the righteous are sustained, yet this order is always rooted in His character, not human systems. The commentary's vivid contrast between Eli's corrupt priesthood and the faithful Samuel underscores Calvin's practical teaching: true worship demands humility and obedience, as God's people must reject pride and corruption to align with His kingdom. Crucially, Calvin saw Samuel's anointing as a direct foreshadowing of Christ—the ultimate anointed one who would establish God's rightful rule. This Christ connection highlights that God's promises to the Davidic line and the priesthood point to Jesus as the fulfillment of covenantal hope, whose authority and sacrificial priesthood surpass all human institutions. For modern readers, Calvin's summary calls for active trust in God's sovereignty amid life's inequalities, urging humility in leadership and a steadfast commitment to Christ as the only true source of redemption and authority, ensuring that true worship remains grounded in divine justice rather than human power. (248 words)

Hannah's song in 1 Samuel 2 reveals profound theological insights through her triumphant prayer following divine intervention. Poole emphasizes that Hannah's joy stems not from worldly success but from God's active salvation—specifically, the miraculous provision of a son to overcome her barrenness and the promise of future blessing. This passage underscores God's absolute uniqueness: He is the only truly holy being and the sole reliable "rock," contrasting sharply with human pride and self-reliance. Poole highlights how God's sovereignty actively reverses human expectations—those who were powerful become weak, the barren conceive, and the hungry are satisfied—demonstrating that divine purposes transcend human logic and temporal circumstances. Theologically, this affirms that true salvation and blessing flow from God's initiative, not human merit, and that His justice and mercy operate in tandem to correct societal imbalances. Practically, this calls believers to cultivate humility in prayer, recognizing God's sovereignty over their circumstances, and avoiding the pride that Hannah's rival Peninnah embodied. It challenges Christians to actively seek God's reversal of injustice rather than clinging to worldly status. Crucially, this song foreshadows Christ: Hannah's son Samuel, anointed by God to shepherd Israel, prefigures Christ as the ultimate "rock" and "savior" who brings divine reversal, restores the broken, and establishes a new covenant through His sacrifice—showing how God's promises in the Old Testament point unambiguously to Christ as the fulfillment of this divine sovereignty and mercy. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 2 reveals Hannah's prayer as a prophetic psalm that transcends personal experience to illuminate God's sovereign rule and Christ's kingdom. Hannah's song, rooted in her barrenness and divine promise, directly foreshadows Christ's reign by emphasizing God's power to reverse human conditions: the mighty fall, the poor rise, and the wicked are crushed. Barnes highlights how this passage functions as a type of Christ's coming kingdom, where God "gives strength unto his king" (1 Samuel 2:10), explicitly connecting to Luke 1:69-70's prophecy of the Messiah. Theologically, this underscores God's transcendence—no other "rock" like Him (1 Samuel 2:2)—and His active justice in judging the earth while lifting the humble. Barnes contrasts this with Eli's corrupt priesthood, showing how human sin (Eli's sons' idolatry) opposes God's intended order, while Samuel's humble calling as "minister" before the Lord exemplifies divine selection beyond human merit. Practically, this calls believers to reject arrogance (1 Samuel 2:3), trust God's provision in unexpected ways (like Hannah's barrenness becoming fulfillment), and actively resist systems of corruption that exploit the vulnerable. The commentary's deepest insight is that Christ's kingdom operates through God's sovereignty over life and death, wealth and poverty, revealing that true victory comes not from human strength but from aligning with the "anointed" ruler who establishes righteousness—urging believers to live with humility and hope in God's redemptive plan. (248 words)

Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 3 emphasizes God's active call and the critical role of obedient response. Samuel's initial experience—where God repeats His voice three times before he learns to say, "Speak, for thy servant heareth"—illustrates that divine communication requires both preparation and faithful reception. Eli's failure to discipline his sons, leading to divine judgment against his house, reveals the gravity of spiritual neglect and the consequences of inaction in leadership. Theologically, this passage underscores God's relentless pursuit of the faithful (His "precious word" in a time of spiritual darkness) and the necessity of humility and accountability. Practical application demands that parents and teachers actively nurture children in Scripture from youth, preparing them to hear and respond to God's voice as Samuel did. Leaders must also confront sin within their own spheres, recognizing that silence complicity perpetuates corruption. Christologically, Samuel foreshadows Christ himself—the true "prophet" who, like Samuel, would be called by God's voice to fulfill a divine purpose (Christ's call to the disciples in Matthew 4:19). Samuel's ministry becomes a pattern for Christ's future role: He who hears God's call and brings the covenantal promise, ultimately offering the ultimate sacrifice for sin. This passage thus challenges believers to cultivate an obedient heart, embrace accountability, and trust that God's call—however repeated—will culminate in the full revelation of His redemptive plan through Christ. (248 words)

Calvin observed that 1 Samuel 3 presents a profound illustration of God's sovereign call and the necessity of attentive obedience, where Samuel's initial confusion mirrors the human condition before divine revelation. The passage reveals that God's voice was precious in those days, yet Eli's blindness and Samuel's lack of understanding highlight the peril of self-reliance. When God called Samuel three times, Calvin emphasized that this repeated summons underscores God's patience and the critical importance of perseverance in listening—not merely to human voices but to the divine. Samuel's eventual obedience, declaring "Speak, for thy servant heareth," becomes a theological model: true prophetic authority flows from aligning one's response with God's sovereign will, not human presumption. This narrative foreshadows Christ, who is the ultimate "Samuel" whose obedience to the Father's voice fulfills God's promises and establishes the New Covenant. Practically, Calvin urged believers to cultivate humility and vigilance, recognizing that God's call is often tested through persistence and the willingness to act on revelation without delay. The passage's enduring application lies in rejecting the false security of self-sufficiency, as Eli's failure to restrain his sons' wickedness demonstrates the cost of neglecting God's voice. Like Samuel, Christians must actively seek God's guidance, trusting that His revelation—whether through Scripture or the Holy Spirit—will transform lives when faithfully received, pointing ultimately to Christ as the fulfillment of God's covenant promises. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 3 illuminates Samuel's pivotal calling as a profound theological narrative about divine revelation and human response. He emphasizes that God's word was "precious" and scarce in those days, meaning prophetic revelation was rare and not openly given to the public, explaining Samuel's initial confusion when called. Eli's failing vision and Samuel's youthful obedience—running to him on the first call—highlight God's deliberate choice to work through a humble, inexperienced servant despite Eli's age and authority. Poole notes Samuel's ignorance of God's voice initially served God's purpose, testing Eli's faith and ensuring Samuel's simplicity became a foundation for divine truth. Theologically, this passage reveals God's persistent, patient communication with the faithful, even when human understanding is limited, and underscores the sacred context of prophetic calling. Practically, it teaches that true obedience requires readiness to hear God's voice—even when the caller is mistaken—emphasizing that spiritual discernment develops through repeated, humble engagement with divine authority. Crucially, Poole connects Samuel's experience to Christ: the "thing" God will do in Israel (1 Samuel 3:11) directly foreshadows Christ's redemptive work, where His coming would shatter the world's foundations, causing profound spiritual shock. Just as Samuel's response ("Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth") becomes the model for believers, Christ's ministry demands active, obedient reception of God's will. This passage thus points to Christ as the ultimate "third call"—the one who fulfills God's promises, judges sin with mercy, and calls His people to a life of attentive obedience, where the true "tingling" in the ears of believers comes from Christ's transformative presence. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 3 reveals profound theological insights about God's personal revelation and the cost of prophetic ministry. The narrative depicts Samuel's initial calling while Eli, elderly and blind, sleeps in the tabernacle—highlighting God's deliberate choice to work through an innocent child to address the failing priesthood. God's threefold call demonstrates His intimate, tangible presence ("the LORD came, and stood") rather than mere auditory impressions, foreshadowing Christ's personhood and direct communication with humanity. The vision's core message—God's judgment against Eli's household for failing to discipline his sons' wickedness (1 Samuel 3:13-14)—exposes a critical theological truth: sin's consequences cannot be resolved by ritual sacrifices alone, a limitation the New Testament resolves through Christ's atoning work (1 John 1:7). This contrast underscores that true purification requires Christ, not ritual observance. Practically, Samuel's obedience to reveal God's word without concealment (1 Samuel 3:18) models the Christian duty to speak truth with humility, even when it challenges loved ones—mirroring Christ's own teaching to endure opposition. For believers today, this passage calls for active engagement with God's voice, courage in sharing difficult truths, and recognition that true spiritual authority flows from Christ's fulfillment of the Old Testament's prophetic promises, where sin's burden is finally lifted through His sacrifice. The chapter thus illuminates the divine call to prophetic responsibility within a redeemed community. (248 words)

Henry observes that 1 Samuel 4 reveals Israel's catastrophic defeat by the Philistines following their desperate, yet ultimately misguided, attempt to secure divine help through ritualistic actions rather than genuine repentance. The people, after being smitten by God's judgment, hastily demanded the ark of the covenant from Shiloh, believing its mere presence would guarantee victory—a profound error Henry identifies as idolatrous reliance on external symbols instead of inward spiritual obedience. Their failure to acknowledge sin (the "accursed thing" within their camp) and the need for humility led to the ark's capture and the death of Eli, the aging judge, who died instantly upon hearing of his sons' murder and the ark's loss. Theologically, Henry emphasizes that God's presence is not a tactical weapon but the source of true salvation, and Israel's tragedy underscores that ritual without repentance becomes a sign of spiritual death. Practically, this warns modern believers against reducing faith to performative religious practices while ignoring personal sin or spiritual neglect—true discipleship requires humility, repentance, and trust in God's character, not ritualistic solutions. Crucially, the ark's removal prefigures Christ as the ultimate "ark" of God's presence and salvation, whose coming resolves the problem of sin and separation. Just as the Philistines feared God's presence in the camp, Christ's arrival brings ultimate victory over enemies and reconciliation, demonstrating that only through Him—whom the ark foreshadowed—can humanity be restored to God's favor and experience true deliverance from sin's bondage.

Calvin observed that the Israelites' desperate plea for the ark of the covenant in 1 Samuel 4 reveals a profound theological failure: their trust in the physical symbol of God's presence, rather than in God's covenant faithfulness, led to catastrophic defeat. The Israelites, defeated in battle and facing the Philistines, sought the ark not as a sign of divine authority but as a temporary military weapon, demonstrating their spiritual blindness and misplaced confidence in rituals over relationship. Calvin emphasized that Eli's death at ninety-eight years—his eyes "dim" and his heart "trembling" for the ark—symbolized how human sin and unfaithfulness sever the connection between God and His people, rendering the temple of God ineffective. The Philistines' terror upon hearing the ark's arrival ("God is come into the camp") underscores God's sovereign presence as both life-giving and life-threatening, a truth Calvin connected to Christ's own divine authority. This passage foreshadows Christ: just as the ark's capture represented the temporary absence of God's presence due to Israel's failure, Christ's crucifixion became the ultimate "taking" of God's glory—yet His resurrection restored it. Practically, Calvin urged believers to reject ritualism and idolatry, recognizing that true salvation depends on Christ alone, not human efforts to "bring God" into battle. Modern Christians must avoid the Israelites' error by centering their faith in Christ's finished work, not in external signs or military solutions, and understanding that God's presence, though terrifying, is ultimately life-giving for those who trust in Him. The naming of Ichabod ("the glory is departed") warns that spiritual neglect leads to the loss of God's blessing, a reality only healed through Christ's atoning presence.

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 4 reveals a profound theological lesson about the dangers of misplaced trust and the necessity of genuine repentance. Poole explains that Israel's initial defeat by the Philistines stemmed from their spiritual corruption—specifically, their idolatry and failure to heed God's warnings (1 Samuel 2)—which rendered them vulnerable despite their outward military strength. When the Israelites urgently sought the Ark of the Covenant to secure victory, they relied on ritual rather than heartfelt confession, believing its presence alone would guarantee deliverance. This misplaced confidence led to temporary initial success (the "great shout" that terrified the Philistines), but their unrepentant hearts ultimately provoked God's judgment: the Ark was captured, and Eli's sons were slain, while Eli himself died in despair. Poole emphasizes that the Ark's power was never meant to be a shield for the unrepentent but a sign of God's presence requiring true humility. Theologically, this narrative underscores that divine favor flows from spiritual renewal, not ritualistic displays. Practically, it warns against treating religious symbols as substitutes for moral transformation—modern believers must prioritize authentic repentance and obedience over superficial religious acts. Crucially, Poole connects this event to Christ as the true "Ark of the Covenant," whose presence (the Incarnate Word) offers redemption where human efforts fail. The Philistines' fear of God's power foreshadows Christ's authority over all enemies, while Israel's downfall illustrates humanity's need for Christ's atoning grace to overcome sin and secure lasting victory. Barnes observes that 1 Samuel 4 depicts Israel's military defeat by the Philistines, prompting elders to demand the ark of the covenant from Shiloh—a decision reflecting Israel's lack of a king and their desperate need for God's direct presence. The narrative reveals profound theological insights: the Philistines' fearful recognition of God's power ("God is come into the camp") demonstrates their acknowledgment of a deity far beyond their understanding, echoing the Exodus plagues and affirming God's absolute sovereignty. Critically, the tragic outcome—Eli's death at ninety-eight, the destruction of the priesthood, and the naming of the child Ichabod ("the glory is departed")—highlights the devastating consequences of spiritual neglect and priestly corruption. Barnes emphasizes that the ark's removal, intended to save Israel, becomes a symbol of divine judgment on unfaithful leadership, foreshadowing the ultimate need for Christ's sacrifice. This event connects powerfully to Christ: the ark, as the dwelling place of God's presence, prefigures Christ as the true "living temple" (John 2:19-21), whose arrival brings salvation but whose absence causes spiritual desolation. Practically, the chapter warns against idolizing human leadership, the dangers of ignoring divine provision, and the urgent need for authentic spiritual renewal. It challenges churches today to vigilantly guard against the "covetousness and profligacy" of leadership, ensuring that the "glory" of God's presence remains central rather than relegated to a broken system—reminding us that true deliverance comes only through Christ, who restores the glory departed. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 5 presents the Philistines' futile attempt to contain the Ark of the Covenant as a profound illustration of divine sovereignty over idolatry and the inevitable consequences of rejecting God. The narrative shows the Philistines, initially triumphant in bringing the Ark to Ashdod, experiencing God's judgment when Dagon, their idol, is destroyed—first falling before the Ark, then cut off, leaving only a stump. Henry emphasizes that this event symbolizes how God's kingdom triumphs over worldly powers and false idols; the Ark represents Christ, the true covenant and source of salvation, whose presence inevitably dismantles sin and corruption. The Philistines' frantic attempts to escape the Ark's influence—moving it to Gath and Ekron—only intensify their destruction, illustrating that those who resist God's authority face severe consequences, as their pride and self-reliance become their downfall. Theologically, Henry connects this to the reality that while Christ's work secures salvation and dethrones sin, the remnants of worldly self-love and sin persist within believers, like the "stump of Dagon." Practically, this calls believers to actively resist these persistent tendencies through continuous repentance and reliance on Christ, rather than seeking self-sufficiency or idolatrous practices. The commentary underscores that true victory comes not from human efforts to control God's presence but from surrendering to His authority, knowing that Christ's triumph in the heart brings lasting renewal and delivers freedom from the power of sin and error.

Calvin interprets 1 Samuel 5 as a profound demonstration of God's sovereign power and the devastating consequences of misplaced worship. The Philistines' attempt to place the Ark of the Covenant beside their idol Dagon—symbolizing their desperate need for divine favor through idolatry—triggers immediate divine judgment. Dagon's destruction, both the initial fall and the complete desecration of his body, illustrates that no idol can withstand God's presence. Calvin emphasizes that the "emerods" (a painful skin affliction) represent God's active, tangible judgment, not distant punishment, showing that divine wrath impacts the community's physical and spiritual well-being. Theologically, this passage reveals that true worship must center on the living God alone; any attempt to align divine authority with false idols invites swift destruction. Practically, it warns against the modern tendency to seek God's favor through rituals or idols—whether cultural practices, personal achievements, or false spiritual authorities—highlighting the urgent need for humility and proper reverence. Christologically, Calvin connects the Ark's journey to Christ as the true "Ark of the Covenant," where divine presence is fully revealed in the person of Jesus. Just as the Philistines' rebellion against God's sovereignty led to their downfall, humanity's rejection of Christ's authority brings spiritual death. This narrative urges believers to flee idolatry in their hearts, embrace Christ as the sole mediator, and live in obedience to a God whose presence is both life-giving and demanding. The passage thus remains a vital lesson for worshiping rightly and fearing God's active, present judgment. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 5 reveals the Philistines' catastrophic encounter with the Ark of the Lord after their idolatrous display at Ashdod. Poole explains that the Philistines, having taken the Ark from Israel, deliberately placed it in Dagon's temple—initially as a trophy of their victory but later as an act of profound disrespect, diminishing their prior reverence. When Dagon fell before the Ark the next morning, his subsequent destruction (head and hands severed) symbolized the complete futility of idol worship, a divine judgment that the Philistines initially concealed but later embraced in their superstition. Poole notes their swift realization that the Ark's presence brought severe plagues (emerods, a painful skin disease) and death, prompting them to relocate it to Gath and eventually Ekron, where similar devastation occurred. Crucially, Poole emphasizes that the Philistines avoided immediate death like Uzzah did because their sin lacked explicit knowledge of God's law; God reserved public judgment for their shame. Theologically, this illustrates God's sovereignty over idolatry and His consistent principle that misplaced worship invites divine wrath. Practically, it warns against treating sacred objects as idols or seeking temporary power through human means. Christologically, the Ark—though a sign in the Old Testament—points to Christ, the true "Ark of the Covenant" (Hebrews 9:4), who alone satisfies God's requirements and bears the curse of sin. The Philistines' fear of the Ark mirrors humanity's fear of Christ, who confronts idolatry and offers salvation through His sacrifice, urging believers to reject false idols and embrace the true God whose presence brings life, not death. (248 words)

Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 5 reveals the profound theological consequence of misplaced worship. The Philistines, having taken the Ark of the Covenant from Ebenezer, attempt to establish it in their temple to Dagon, believing this would secure their triumph over the God of Israel. Their actions trigger immediate divine judgment: Dagon falls lifeless before the Ark, his head and hands severed, a sign that the idol they revered was utterly destroyed by the presence of the true God. This event, Barnes emphasizes, underscores God's absolute sovereignty over idolatry and the futility of human attempts to control divine power through false gods. The Philistines' subsequent terror—manifested in emerods (a severe form of hemorrhoids) and widespread destruction—demonstrates God's just response to persistent idolatry, showing that divine judgment is not arbitrary but follows the pattern of covenant faithfulness. Practically, this narrative warns against the dangers of idolizing human achievements, political power, or self-reliance, urging believers to recognize that true worship must center on God alone. Theologically, the Ark's journey through Philistine cities foreshadows Christ as the true Temple and the ultimate solution to idolatry; just as the Philistines feared the Ark's presence, sinners fear Christ's authority. Christ's crucifixion and resurrection resolve the conflict between humanity and divine holiness, offering salvation where the Philistines' false gods failed. This passage thus challenges modern readers to examine their hearts for misplaced loyalty, ensuring worship remains rooted in the one true God who alone can deliver from spiritual death.

Henry observes that the Philistines' seven-month punishment for keeping the ark of the LORD reveals a profound theological truth: God's discipline arises when people refuse to release their sins, just as the Philistines' failure to return the ark caused prolonged plagues. Their subsequent attempt to appease God through a trespass offering—five golden emerods and mice—highlights the critical need for humble restitution before divine justice. The ark's journey to Bethshemesh, guided by God's providence through the milch kine, demonstrates His sovereignty in restoring His presence where faith meets reverence. Yet the tragic consequence—Bethshemesh's 1,170 deaths for looking into the ark—exposes the peril of presumptuous curiosity, teaching that God's holiness demands boundaries: no one may meddle with sacred things without proper humility. This narrative connects directly to Christ, who is the true and sufficient "ark" (Colossians 2:9), fulfilling the need for atonement that the Philistines' offerings could not. The punishment of Bethshemesh warns against rejecting God's grace in favor of ritualistic solutions while the ark remains; it underscores that true reconciliation requires repentance, not mere ritual. Practically, this calls believers to approach God's presence with deep reverence, avoiding the Philistines' error of treating divine authority as a bargaining chip. It challenges modern Christians to seek Christ's forgiveness through faith alone, not human rituals, and to resist the temptation to "look into" God's work with pride—knowing that only Christ's blood covers the sin that would otherwise provoke divine judgment. The story remains a timeless reminder that God's grace is both a gift and a test of our hearts.

Calvin interprets 1 Samuel 6 as a profound illustration of divine sovereignty, human accountability, and the necessity of proper reverence before God. He emphasizes that the Philistines' seven-month possession of the Ark—symbolizing God's presence—revealed their idolatry and spiritual blindness, as they sought a "trespass offering" (v. 3) rather than repentance. Calvin notes the specific offerings—five golden emerods and mice—symbolize the Philistines' collective sin and the need for humility, while the cart's unyielding path to Bethshemesh demonstrates God's active providence in executing justice. Crucially, Calvin highlights the devastating consequence for Bethshemesh when they improperly gazed upon the Ark without understanding its holiness, resulting in a plague that underscores God's absolute transcendence and the peril of unworthy worship. Theologically, this episode reveals God's intolerance for idolatry and His demand for repentance, where the Philistines' temporary victory over the Ark becomes a lesson in submission. Christologically, Calvin connects the Ark's return to Christ as the ultimate "trespass offering"—the atoning sacrifice that resolves sin's consequences. The Philistines' repentance through the offering prefigures Christ's role as the true Ark, whose sacrifice reconciles us to God. Practically, this passage calls believers to examine their relationship with God: to avoid idolatrous practices, approach sacred things with humility, and recognize that God's presence demands reverence, not casual observation. It warns against the danger of spiritual complacency, urging us to seek Christ's forgiveness and proper alignment with His will, lest we face the consequences of unworthy worship. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 6 reveals the Philistines' desperate attempt to return the Ark of the Lord after its seven-month stay in their land, highlighting profound theological truths. Poole emphasizes that the Philistines, guided by their diviners, offered a "trespass offering" of five golden emerods (symbols of their swollen, diseased bodies) and mice (representing crop destruction), seeking divine healing while acknowledging their sin. The critical moment occurs when two untamed milch kine, tied to a new cart, miraculously travel the straight path to Beth-shemesh without deviation—a sign God intended to demonstrate His sovereignty over the Philistines' idolatry and confusion. Poole connects this event to the Exodus narrative, where Pharaoh's hardened heart contrasted with God's miraculous deliverance, showing that human resistance to divine guidance leads to destruction. Theologically, the Ark symbolizes God's presence, and the Philistines' failure to understand its true nature exposes the universal human tendency to seek solutions in idols rather than acknowledge Christ as the only true sacrifice for sin. Practically, this narrative warns against spiritual complacency: believers must actively confront sin (like the emerods), recognize the consequences of idolatry (the mice), and trust God's guidance in times of crisis—just as the kine obeyed the Ark's path without human interference. Christologically, the Ark points to Jesus as the true "place of God's presence" (Hebrews 9:24), and the trespass offering prefigures Christ's atoning death—where sin is fully paid for, and believers find healing through His sacrifice, not human rituals. This passage urges Christians to return to God with humility, trusting His power to work in their lives as the kine's path revealed divine purpose. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 6 reveals profound theological insights into God's relational dynamics and the consequences of human presumption. The Philistines, after seven months of divine judgment, sought repentance through a trespass offering—five golden emerods and mice—symbolizing both their acknowledgment of guilt and a desire for God's mercy. Barnes emphasizes that the Philistines' actions, though pagan in origin, aligned with scriptural principles of penitence and restitution, showing how God's grace can be accessed through proper reverence and costly sacrifice. The ark's return via a new cart with unyoked milch kine, which traveled straight to Bethshemesh without deviation, demonstrated divine sovereignty over natural tendencies—mirroring Christ's path of redemption and the certainty of God's will. However, the tragic punishment of Bethshemesh for gazing at the ark underscores a critical lesson: intimate communion with the holy demands reverence, not casual joy. Barnes connects this event to the need for proper spiritual boundaries, noting that the people's celebration likely involved presumption, reflecting how sin manifests in the absence of disciplined worship. Theologically, this passage illustrates God's character—both just in judgment and gracious in restoration—while revealing that true worship requires humility. Practically, it warns against treating divine presence as a mere spectacle; modern believers must avoid idolatrous attitudes toward spiritual gifts and maintain reverence in worship. Christologically, the Ark points to Christ as the true "treasure" (John 20:19), and the Philistines' offering foreshadows Christ's atoning sacrifice—where humanity's sinfulness demands costly redemption, not mere ritual. The Bethshemesh incident also highlights that God's justice cannot be bypassed by human enthusiasm, emphasizing that only Christ's atoning work reconciles us to God. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 7 presents a profound narrative of Israel's repentance and divine deliverance, revealing crucial theological principles for modern believers. After twenty years of lamenting God's absence, the Israelites, under Samuel's leadership, decisively abandoned idolatry and made a public confession of sin at Mizpeh—a powerful act of humility where they poured out water before the Lord, symbolizing their brokenness and commitment to return to God alone. Henry emphasizes that this revival centered not on ritualistic restoration of the ark (which remained in a private home) but on heartfelt repentance and a renewed covenant relationship, illustrating that God's presence is found where genuine spiritual transformation occurs, not merely in institutional structures. The subsequent victory over the Philistines, secured through Samuel's intercessory prayer and God's thunderous intervention, demonstrates God's active care for those who turn away from sin. Crucially, Henry connects this to Christ: Samuel's role as intercessor prefigures Jesus as the ultimate High Priest who continually prays for the faithful (Hebrews 4:14-16), while the "Ebenezer" stone—meaning "stone of help"—becomes a timeless symbol of Christ's victory over sin and enemies, reminding believers that God's deliverance is rooted in His faithfulness to the repentant heart. Practically, this calls believers to prioritize authentic repentance and confession in times of spiritual distress, actively seeking God's help rather than relying on external circumstances, and trusting that Christ's intercession ensures victory through obedience to His Word—just as the Israelites found freedom from the Philistines through surrender to God's guidance. (248 words)

Calvin observed that 1 Samuel 7 reveals Israel's profound dependence on God's covenant faithfulness amid persistent sin and external threat, emphasizing the transformative power of genuine repentance. The twenty-year period the ark remained at Kirjathjearim underscores Israel's prolonged lamentation and spiritual struggle, a period Calvin saw as a necessary reckoning where God's presence demanded communal restoration. Samuel's call to dismantle idolatry and fully commit to the Lord highlights the theological reality that true worship requires radical abandonment of false gods—a process Calvin understood as essential for spiritual renewal. The gathering at Mizpeh, with its water offering, fasting, and confession, exemplifies communal repentance as a vital prerequisite for divine intervention. Calvin stressed that Samuel's intercession—offering a burnt sacrifice and pleading for Israel—prefigures Christ's role as the ultimate mediator whose atoning sacrifice reconciles humanity to God. The victory over the Philistines, secured through God's thunderous intervention, demonstrates that God's deliverance flows from covenant faithfulness, not human strength. Practically, this passage urges believers to actively return to God with repentance when facing spiritual or relational battles, seeking His help through confession and prayer rather than self-reliance. The Ebenezer stone, meaning "hitherto the Lord has helped us," serves as a timeless reminder that God's active presence and power are sufficient for victory, pointing forward to Christ who, as the "hitherto" of salvation, defeats all enemies through His finished work. This narrative thus calls Christians to trust God's sustaining power in their struggles, knowing His help is both immediate and enduring.

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 7 reveals a profound theological narrative where Israel's repentance and communal restoration become central. Poole emphasizes that the Israelites' prolonged lamentation over the ark's presence at Kirjath-jearim (twenty years) stemmed not from the ark's fault but their own sin—idolatry and spiritual neglect—highlighting that divine deliverance requires internal repentance, not external ritual. Samuel's call to "put away the strange gods" (v. 3) underscores the necessity of purging idolatry from both hearts and homes, a call Poole interprets as demanding genuine conversion, not mere compliance. The Mizpeh gathering, where Israel poured water before the Lord and fasted in sincere lamentation ("we have sinned"), exemplifies authentic repentance: an external sign of internal cleansing, reflecting the need for communal accountability and humility before God. Poole notes this ritual's significance—water symbolizing both external purification and the spiritual cleansing only possible through divine grace. Theologically, this episode demonstrates God's responsiveness to heartfelt repentance and communal prayer, directly contrasting Israel's past idolatry with their present restoration. Practically, it challenges modern believers to examine whether their worship is truly heart-centered or ritualistic, urging collective repentance when sin festers. Christologically, Samuel's intercessory prayer (v. 11) prefigures Christ as the ultimate mediator between God and humanity—his atoning sacrifice resolving the sin that once plagued Israel. Just as the ark's recovery from Philistine oppression (v. 14) signifies God's triumph over oppression, Christ's victory over sin and death offers restoration to all who repent and turn to Him, making this ancient narrative a timeless call to humility, communal repentance, and trust in divine deliverance. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 7 reveals a pivotal moment of national restoration where Samuel, acting as prophet, judge, and leader, guides Israel through profound repentance after decades of Philistine oppression. The Israelites' prolonged lamentation over the ark's relocation to Kirjathjearim—twenty years after the Philistines' initial capture—reflects deep spiritual decline due to idolatry and neglect, a consequence of their failure to honor God's covenant. Samuel's urgent call for total abandonment of false gods and a renewed commitment to Yahweh demonstrates the necessity of genuine repentance, not merely verbal remorse. His subsequent gathering at Mizpeh, involving water-pouring rituals symbolizing cleansing and fasting expressing remorse, showcases communal penitence as a prerequisite for divine intervention. The dramatic victory over the Philistines, triggered by Samuel's burnt offering of a lamb—a sacrifice uniquely significant in the Pentateuch—highlights God's responsiveness to authentic prayer and atonement. This event underscores a key theological truth: God actively engages with repentant communities, restoring covenant relationships when faithfulness is restored. Practically, it calls Israelites today to examine their communal worship, address idolatry in modern forms (like spiritual apathy or materialism), and foster collective repentance when facing oppression. Theologically, Samuel's intercession anticipates Christ's role as the ultimate High Priest who intercedes perpetually (Hebrews 7:23-25), while the "lamb" sacrifice points to Christ's sacrificial death as the true means of reconciliation. This passage thus offers a timeless application: when communities feel God's distance, they must first repent and seek His presence through faithful leadership and communal renewal, trusting that His power—like the thunder that defeated the Philistines—will prevail when His people align with His will. (248 words)

Henry observes that 1 Samuel 8 reveals Israel's tragic descent from divine governance to demanding a human king, highlighting Samuel's sons' corruption—taking bribes and perverting justice—while the people, threatened by invasion, pressed Samuel for leadership. Theologically, this underscores God's profound displeasure with Israel's idolatry: they rejected God's sovereign rule not out of rebellion against Him but by pursuing worldly power, thereby aligning themselves with sin's system. God's response, though granting their request, warns of the crushing burdens of kingship: land seizures, forced labor, familial exploitation, and the ultimate consequence of being silenced when they cry out. Practically, this calls believers to resist the allure of earthly authority structures, recognizing that true leadership requires sacrificial humility—contrasted sharply with the exploitation described. Crucially, Henry connects this narrative to Christ: Jesus is the fulfillment of the promised king who reverses the pattern, offering liberation through sacrificial service rather than exploitation. His kingdom demands costly discipleship—surrendering possessions, time, and autonomy for others—without the heavy yoke of oppression. This passage challenges modern readers to examine their own cravings for power or status, praying for rulers who govern "in the fear of the Lord" and to embrace Christ's alternative kingship, where true freedom flows from selfless obedience, not earthly dominion. The people's refusal to heed Samuel's warnings mirrors our tendency to prioritize temporary comfort over covenant faithfulness, urging us to seek Christ's kingdom first. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on 1 Samuel 8 reveals a profound theological warning about Israel's spiritual decline and the peril of seeking human rulership over God's covenant. Observing Samuel's sons' corruption—turning from divine stewardship to greed and bribery—Calvin emphasizes how the people's demand for a king signifies a rejection of God's direct rule in favor of worldly power structures. Samuel's pivotal declaration that God "will not hear you" if they choose a king (v. 18) underscores the critical insight that true authority must align with divine sovereignty, not human ambition. Calvin connects this to the broader narrative: Israel's request mirrors humanity's recurring pattern of seeking rulers who inevitably enslave them to systems of oppression, as prophesied in the king's demands for labor, resources, and family sacrifice. Theologically, this illustrates God's covenant faithfulness being tested when people prioritize external order over internal spiritual renewal. Practically, it challenges believers to resist the idolatry of political power—refusing to accept systems that exploit the vulnerable, especially when such systems promise security but deliver bondage. Crucially, Calvin links this to Christ: the true King who fulfills the promise of liberation, not oppression. Unlike the human king described, Christ establishes a kingdom where true freedom flows from grace, not servitude to human authority. This passage thus calls Christians to reject worldly kingship structures, trusting Christ's kingdom where justice and restoration reign, rather than perpetuating cycles of exploitation through misplaced allegiance to human power. (248 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 8 reveals a profound theological warning about the human desire for political authority. As Samuel grows old and his sons—Joel and Abiah—become corrupt, taking bribes and perverting justice, the Israelite elders demand a king to judge them like other nations. Poole stresses that Samuel's deep distress stems not from their complaint about his sons alone, but from their fundamental rejection of God's direct rule, revealing a dangerous idolatry in seeking human kingship. God's response, through Samuel, explicitly warns that kings will exploit the people: taking sons for chariots and horses, imposing heavy taxes, and subjecting them to tyranny. Theologically, Poole underscores that the people's sin lies not in desiring a king (as Deuteronomy permits) but in pursuing it with sinful motives—ambition, distrust of God, and a rejection of His sovereign governance. This foreshadows Christ's true kingship: unlike worldly rulers who exploit the vulnerable, Jesus voluntarily gives Himself as the ultimate "son" (the Lamb) for His people, never taking them for His chariots but liberating them through sacrifice. Practically, this commentary urges believers to examine their own desires for authority, resisting the temptation to prioritize power over service. It calls for humility in leadership, recognizing that true kingship flows from God's grace, not human ambition, and reminds us that Christ's coming resolves the problem of oppressive rule by offering a kingdom where the servant leads and the people are restored, not subjugated. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 8 reveals Israel's critical pattern of rejecting God's anointed leadership for human systems of power. As Samuel grew old and his sons became corrupt, taking bribes and perverting justice (v. 3), the people demanded a king like other nations—a request that deeply displeased Samuel, who saw it as a rejection of God's sovereign rule (v. 7). God's response underscores the theological truth that Israel's persistent choice for visible, earthly authority—instead of trusting the invisible, covenantal Lord—was a rejection of Him, not merely Samuel. The detailed warnings about the king's burdens—taking sons for military service, daughters for domestic labor, fields, tithes, and even livestock (v. 11-18)—highlight the profound cost of political leadership that exploits the vulnerable. This foreshadows Christ's fulfillment: Jesus' kingdom reverses these patterns, offering liberation from oppressive systems rather than demanding servitude. Practically, this commentary warns against idolizing political power structures that prioritize human control over divine stewardship, urging believers to resist the temptation to seek rulership that exploits others. Theologically, it illustrates that true kingship is relational and sacrificial, contrasting sharply with worldly systems. Christ, as the ultimate King, embodies this reversal—serving the weak and poor while granting freedom from exploitation, calling believers to embrace spiritual authority rooted in grace rather than human authority that demands tribute and labor. (248 words)

Henry observes that 1 Samuel 9 presents a profound narrative of divine sovereignty meeting human humility. Saul's diligent search for his father's lost asses—traversing vast territories without success—becomes the unexpected pathway to his calling as Israel's future king. Henry emphasizes that God's purpose transcends worldly pursuits; Saul's initial obedience to his father (seeking the asses) contrasts sharply with his later anointing, illustrating how God uses ordinary circumstances to select extraordinary servants. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereign choice of the "least" (Saul from Benjamin's smallest family) to fulfill His purpose, foreshadowing Christ's identity as the ultimate anointed one who would save His people. Practical application demands that we cease fixating on material losses or worldly success, recognizing that God's true gifts—like spiritual guidance—often emerge from humble, obedient steps. When life feels lost, we must seek wisdom beyond immediate concerns, just as Saul's servant offered a small silver coin to Samuel—a symbolic gesture of respect that opened the door to divine revelation. Crucially, Henry connects this story to Christ: Samuel's anointing of Saul prefigures Christ as the true king anointed by the Holy Spirit (Acts 10:38), whose coming fulfills God's promise to deliver Israel from spiritual and physical oppression. This narrative challenges us to abandon self-centered ambitions and trust God's timing, understanding that the kingdom He offers is far more valuable than earthly possessions, and that true fulfillment comes through surrendering to His sovereign plan. (248 words)

John Calvin's commentary on 1 Samuel 9 emphasizes God's sovereign predestination and the profound significance of divine calling, particularly through the anointing of Saul. Calvin observes that God, knowing Saul's future role, deliberately orchestrated events—Saul's lost donkeys and his encounter with Samuel—to select a man of exceptional character for leadership. This narrative reveals God's active providence: He works through human circumstances and humble beginnings to fulfill His purposes, ensuring that the chosen individual (Saul) is not self-appointed but divinely appointed. Theologically, Calvin stresses that true calling involves both God's initiative and the candidate's readiness, yet ultimate authority rests solely with God. The practical application for believers is clear: they must remain vigilant for God's signals in ordinary life, avoiding self-reliance or pride in their circumstances, while actively seeking His guidance without presumption. Crucially, Calvin connects this event to Christ by noting that Samuel's anointing of Saul prefigures Christ's anointing as the ultimate "seer" and fulfiller of God's promises. Just as Saul was chosen from the smallest tribe to lead Israel, Christ is the divine anointed, chosen before time began, whose mission transcends human limitations. This underscores that all true leadership and purpose flow from God's sovereign will, not human merit, urging believers to trust Christ's anointing and live in service to His kingdom, recognizing their role as instruments of God's grace in a world needing redemption. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 9 reveals profound theological insights through Saul's humble initiation. He describes Kish, a Benjamite "mighty man of power" (likely meaning courageous, not wealthy), whose son Saul—strikingly handsome and tall—loses his father's valuable asses. Saul and his servant, initially desperate and resource-poor, seek divine guidance by visiting a "seer" (prophet) in Ziph. Poole emphasizes the cultural context: the small silver gift Saul's servant offers, though seemingly meager, reflects ancient practices where respect and gratitude were expressed through modest provision. Crucially, the young maidens' role in directing them to Samuel underscores God's active involvement in ordinary life, revealing His providence even in minor circumstances. Theologically, this narrative illustrates God's sovereign choice of an unlikely vessel—Saul, a humble youth—to become king, foreshadowing His practice of elevating the lowly. Practical applications highlight humility in seeking God's direction, especially when circumstances seem dire or resources scarce. It teaches that true leadership begins with submission to divine guidance, not self-reliance. Christologically, this scene prefigures Christ's anointing: just as Samuel anointed Saul for a kingly role, God anoints believers for service, emphasizing that divine purpose transcends human status. Poole underscores that God's revelation often arrives through unexpected channels—here, the maidens—reminding us that faith requires openness to God's guidance in the mundane, where Christ's kingdom operates through humble, ordinary people called to respond to His provision.

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 9 reveals how God sovereignly initiates leadership through ordinary circumstances. The narrative details Kish, a Benjamite, losing his donkeys and sending his son Saul—a man of exceptional physical stature—to find them. Despite Saul's initial humility and the family's poverty (offering only a quarter shekel of silver), God directs Samuel, who has been divinely prepared, to anoint Saul as Israel's future king. Barnes emphasizes the significance of the "seer" designation, noting its earlier use in Israel before prophets became common, highlighting the continuity of God's authoritative guidance. Theologically, this passage underscores God's choice of individuals beyond their social status or perceived worth—Saul, a descendant of a tribe nearly annihilated in the civil war, is selected despite his apparent insignificance. Practically, it teaches that faithful obedience in seemingly minor tasks (like seeking lost donkeys) can become the pathway to God's purpose, while the quarter shekel symbolizes trusting God for provision without overestimating human resources. Crucially, Barnes connects this event to Christ: Samuel's anointing of Saul prefigures Christ as the ultimate "Seer" and true anointed one, whose coming fulfills God's promise to save His people. Saul's journey—from lost donkeys to kingship—mirrors Christ's calling, where divine purpose operates through humble, obedient faith in ordinary moments, reminding believers that God's sovereign choice transcends human limitations and calls for trust in His timing and provision. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 10 reveals how Samuel's anointing of Saul serves as a profound type of Christ's divine appointment. Henry emphasizes that the oil Samuel poured upon Saul's head symbolized not merely political authority but the Spirit's transformative work, pointing directly to Christ—the true Anointed One who was anointed with the "oil of the Spirit without measure" (Hebrews 1:9). While the signs Samuel provided—Saul encountering prophets, prophesying, and being recognized—demonstrated God's sovereign confirmation, Henry cautions that Saul's "new heart" was temporary and superficial, failing to produce lasting transformation. This contrasts sharply with Christ, whose anointing by the Spirit results in permanent, eternal renewal. Theologically, Henry underscores that God's call involves both divine initiative and human response, yet true obedience requires humility and trust, not mere outward compliance. Practically, this passage instructs believers to avoid mistaking fleeting spiritual experiences for lasting change, urging genuine humility before God and careful discernment of true spiritual awakening. It also warns against the temptation to seek immediate results or popularity in service to God, as Saul's initial success quickly led to his isolation. Crucially, Henry connects Saul's story to Christ's fulfillment: just as Saul's anointing was a precursor to Israel's monarchy, Christ's anointing established the eternal kingdom where true worship and authority flow from the Spirit's indwelling. Modern readers should therefore cultivate deep humility, prioritize authentic spiritual transformation over external validation, and recognize that God's call—like Christ's anointing—requires steadfast faith and obedience, not temporary signs or political ambition. (248 words)

Calvin observed that Samuel's anointing of Saul in 1 Samuel 10 exemplifies God's sovereign appointment of leadership through divine signs, not human initiative. The specific instructions—finding the asses, meeting the prophets, and the Spirit's empowering presence—were not mere coincidence but visible manifestations of God's active commissioning. Calvin emphasized that these signs, particularly the Spirit descending upon Saul to enable prophetic speech, reveal that true leadership originates from God's initiative, not personal ambition. Crucially, Calvin connected Saul's experience to Christ, noting that just as the Spirit anointed Saul for a temporary role in Israel's history, Christ is the eternal anointed One whose Spirit empowers the New Covenant community. This anointing transcends mere political authority, pointing to spiritual renewal and divine purpose. Practically, Calvin urged believers to discern God's call in their lives through signs of the Spirit's presence—such as conviction, service, and prophetic clarity—rather than seeking power through human means. He stressed that leadership requires humility, as seen when Saul initially faced rejection from his own people; this mirrors Christ's call for followers to prioritize God's kingdom over personal glory. The chapter warns against the danger of premature acceptance of leadership without divine confirmation, a lesson vital for modern Christians navigating roles of authority. Ultimately, Calvin concluded that God's choice is always sovereign, and true leaders must align their actions with His purpose, recognizing that Christ's anointing—the Spirit's indwelling—provides the enduring foundation for authentic leadership that transforms communities. (248 words)

Poole emphasizes that Samuel's anointing of Saul with oil (1 Samuel 10:1) signifies God's sovereign appointment, not Saul's personal ambition, with the oil symbolizing the Spirit's empowering presence for kingship. He details the three divine signs Saul would receive: the found asses at Rachel's tomb, the sacrificial bread at Tabor, and the prophetic assembly at the hill of God where the Spirit would descend upon him, transforming him into "another man"—a sudden infusion of divine wisdom, courage, and prophetic authority. Poole interprets this ritual as a pattern for all God-appointed leadership, where the anointing signifies spiritual empowerment rather than mere ritualistic tradition. Theologically, this underscores that true kingship originates from God's will, not human desire; Saul's initial humility (concealing the kingdom's nature) and subsequent responsibility require divine alignment. Practically, it warns against self-determined leadership, urging believers to seek God's specific direction and spiritual readiness before taking public roles. Christologically, Poole connects Saul's anointing to Christ's own anointing by the Spirit (Luke 4:18-21), showing that both were instruments of God's kingdom—Saul as a foreshadowing of Christ's kingly authority, empowered by the Spirit for prophetic and regal service. This highlights that all effective leadership, whether in the Old or New Covenant, must be rooted in divine calling and the transformative power of the Holy Spirit, not human ambition. (248 words)

Barnes emphasizes that Samuel's anointing of Saul in 1 Samuel 10 functions as a divine confirmation process, where God actively works through specific signs to validate Saul's calling. The narrative details three prophetic encounters—finding the asses at Rachel's tomb, meeting the three men at Tabor, and encountering the prophetic company at Gibeah—each designed to demonstrate God's direct involvement rather than human decision-making. Theologically, this reveals God's sovereign appointment of leaders through visible, experiential signs that transcend Saul's initial self-perception, highlighting that true authority flows from God's initiative, not human merit. Crucially, Barnes connects this to Christ by underscoring that Saul's temporary prophetic experience (where "the Spirit of the LORD will come upon thee") prefigures Christ's unique anointing, where the Spirit indwells for eternal purpose—unlike temporary spiritual gifts in Saul's case. The phrase "he shall be turned into another man" points to a transformative empowerment, foreshadowing Christ's work of spiritual renewal. Practically, believers should seek God's confirmation through intentional signs of His presence in their lives, avoiding premature leadership without spiritual readiness. This chapter teaches that true leadership requires humility, trust in God's timing, and recognition that authority must be surrendered to divine purpose—just as Saul initially understood his calling was contingent on God's sign, not his own ambition. The prophetic community's reaction ("Is Saul also among the prophets?") underscores the reality that God's anointed must be recognized through divine work, not human judgment, a principle vital for modern leaders navigating spiritual authority. (248 words)

Matthew Henry's commentary on 1 Samuel 11 emphasizes how Saul's decisive action in rescuing Jabesh-gilead from the Ammonite threat reveals God's sovereign power operating through faithful leadership. When the Ammonites threatened the Israelites with eye-removal, Saul's initial hesitation transformed into courageous intervention after hearing of the crisis. The Spirit of God empowered him immediately, leading to a swift mobilization of the entire nation—three hundred thousand men of Israel and thirty thousand of Judah—demonstrating that God's authority inspires collective response to danger. Henry highlights the profound theological insight that true power in leadership flows from God's initiative, not human ambition; Saul's success stemmed from his submission to divine purpose, not his own strength. This event foreshadows Christ as the ultimate anointed one whose authority will overcome opposition. Practically, it teaches believers to respond to crises with urgency rooted in faith, avoiding passive despair when God's Spirit moves. The "fear of the LORD" described here is not mere dread but obedient respect that prompts action, urging modern readers to align their efforts with God's will rather than self-preservation. Crucially, Henry connects this moment to Christ's future reign: just as Saul was initially despised but later honored as king, Christ—rejected by many—will ultimately be acknowledged as the true anointed ruler who brings salvation. This narrative thus calls Christians to trust God's power in their leadership, embrace timely obedience, and recognize that Christ's victory over enemies begins with the same faith that mobilized Israel in Saul's day. (280 words)

John Calvin's commentary on 1 Samuel 11 emphasizes God's sovereign providence in the crisis of Jabesh-Gilead. He observes that the Ammonite threat, though seemingly dire, becomes an opportunity for divine intervention when Saul responds not to fear but to the people's cry for help. Calvin highlights how God's Spirit empowers Saul, transforming him from a military leader into a instrument of God's will—showing that true leadership arises from responsiveness to divine call, not human ambition. Crucially, Calvin connects this event to Christ's ultimate sovereignty: Saul's temporary kingship, though divinely ordained here, points forward to Christ as the true King who "reigns over all" (1 Samuel 11:13). The people's immediate obedience to Saul's call, driven by the "fear of the LORD," foreshadows the church's dependence on Christ's authority rather than human power. Practically, Calvin stresses that modern leaders must cultivate this divine sensitivity—responding to crises with humility and urgency, avoiding the Ammonite's demand for blind submission to oppression. The passage warns against self-reliance, urging believers to recognize God's active role in their struggles, just as the Israelites' victory came through collective faith in God's promise. For Christians today, this story illustrates that true strength flows from Christ's authority, not human might, and that leadership must always be anchored in divine purpose rather than political or military dominance. (248 words)

Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 11 emphasizes the pivotal role of divine empowerment and responsible leadership in crisis. When Nahash the Ammonite threatens Jabesh-Gilead with a degrading covenant—thrusting out their right eyes—their plea for seven days to seek help reveals a community facing existential peril due to perceived helplessness. Saul's immediate response, marked by the Spirit of God descending upon him, demonstrates God's active involvement in empowering genuine leadership when individuals face injustice. His decisive action—hewing oxen and issuing a warning that triggers the "fear of the LORD" among Israelites—shows that true authority stems from divine commission, not self-seeking ambition. This event foreshadows Christ's authority: just as Saul mobilized Israel through faith in God's provision, Christ empowers believers to act with courage and unity in opposition to oppression. The practical application highlights the necessity of timely, decisive action rooted in trust—responding to crises with unity and obedience rather than delay or self-preservation. Theologically, Poole underscores that God's sovereignty is evident in the mobilization of the people (330,000 Israelites plus 30,000 Judah), revealing how faithful communities, when called to action, become instruments of divine justice. This narrative prefigures Christ's ultimate victory over spiritual and physical enemies, illustrating that leadership empowered by the Spirit transforms fear into faith and division into unity, preparing the way for the Messiah who will conquer all opposition through divine authority. (248 words)

Albert Barnes's commentary on 1 Samuel 11 reveals a pivotal moment where God empowers an ordinary man to respond to national crisis. Nahash the Ammonite threatens Jabesh-Gilead with brutal eye removal, prompting the elders to seek a seven-day respite. Saul, then a humble farmer near Gibeah, hears the news and experiences a sudden, powerful outpouring of the Spirit, transforming him into a leader. His immediate action—hewing oxen and sending a decree of terror—demonstrates God's sovereignty in mobilizing faith through divine initiative rather than human ambition. The swift victory against the Ammonites, achieved through strategic military organization and unified community response, illustrates how God's fear (reverence for Him) can overcome overwhelming threats. Theologically, this event underscores that true leadership emerges from responsiveness to divine call, not established authority. Practically, it teaches believers to mobilize faith quickly in crises, leveraging community strength and divine timing rather than delay. Christologically, this scene foreshadows Christ's ultimate triumph over sin and death. Just as Saul's action stemmed from God's initiative to save Israel, Christ's victory over evil required divine intervention—his sacrificial death and resurrection. The "fear of the LORD" experienced by the Israelites prefigures the Christian's reverence for Christ as the ultimate sovereign who conquers all enemies. This passage thus connects ancient leadership to Christ's mission: true power flows from obedience to God's call, and the church must respond with unity and swift action when God mobilizes His people for His purposes. (248 words)

Samuel's speech in 1 Samuel 12 offers a profound theological and practical lesson for believers. He first defends his integrity before the people, affirming his honesty and calling them to witness his innocence (v1-5), a reminder that leaders must uphold their character under scrutiny. His subsequent historical argument (v6-15) reveals God's sovereign care: He delivered Israel from Egypt, protected them through judges, and ultimately set Samuel himself as their prophet. This narrative underscores that God's power, not human ambition, is the true source of deliverance. Crucially, Samuel's dramatic appeal for thunder and rain (v17-18) serves as a divine warning—showing the people's sin in demanding a human king rather than God's kingdom—highlighting that true salvation requires acknowledging God's authority, not human solutions. Theologically, this passage reveals God's justice and covenant faithfulness: He will not abandon His people (v22), but rebellion incurs His judgment (v25). Practically, it warns against idolatry in leadership—modern believers must avoid placing human authority above Christ, especially in church governance. The Christ connection is central: Samuel's anointed king (Saul) was a temporary figure, while Christ is the eternal King who fulfills the people's deepest need (v13). Just as Samuel's thunderstorm exposed the futility of human kingship, Christ's atonement provides true security and deliverance from sin's wrath. The passage urges believers to "fear the LORD" (v24), not through fear of punishment alone, but through gratitude for God's redemptive acts—encouraging authentic worship and obedience that avoids "vain things" (v21). This timeless message calls us to seek Christ as our true king, whose kingdom brings lasting peace, not temporary human rule. (248 words)

Calvin's commentary on 1 Samuel 12 emphasizes the profound theological tension between God's sovereign rule and human desires for political authority. Samuel's declaration before Israel—where he meticulously testifies to his own integrity and the people's lack of wrongdoing—serves as a crucial witness to God's unwavering commitment to His covenant. Calvin highlights that the people's request for a king reveals a deeper spiritual rebellion: their idolatry of human leadership over God's divine kingship, a pattern repeated throughout Israel's history where they rejected God's direct rule for temporal power. This demand foreshadows Christ's ultimate role as the true King who inaugurates a kingdom of grace, not political dominion. Calvin stresses that God's judgment in the thunderstorm was not arbitrary but a divine sign of the people's spiritual condition—showing that their rebellion against God's direct rule had severe consequences. Practically, this passage calls believers to reject all forms of worldly authority that substitute for Christ's lordship, urging genuine obedience to God's commandments rather than political expediency. Theologically, Calvin insists that true kingship—where God's people "fear the LORD and serve Him with all their heart"—is the only path to enduring blessing, as the people's rebellion guarantees their destruction without Christ. The passage thus provides a timeless warning: any attempt to establish human rule over God's people inevitably leads to spiritual death, while Christ's kingship offers redemption through faith in His sacrificial death and resurrection, transforming the nature of leadership from earthly power to divine grace. (249 words)

Matthew Poole's commentary on 1 Samuel 12 reveals Samuel's profound wisdom in addressing Israel's request for a king after Saul's appointment. Samuel meticulously testifies to his own integrity, explicitly stating he has never oppressed, defrauded, or taken bribes, positioning himself as a transparent witness against his own conduct. This act of self-revelation serves a deeper theological purpose: he preempts the people's potential idolatry by connecting their desire for human leadership to God's prior covenantal deliverance through Moses and Aaron. Poole emphasizes that Samuel's warning against rejecting God's anointed king (Saul) stems from his understanding of the people's need for holy fear and repentance, not self-interest. Crucially, Poole draws Christological significance here, noting that Samuel's role as a witness before God and the anointed king foreshadows Christ's own self-revelation and testimony. Just as Samuel's integrity was foundational to his warning, Christ's humility and witness against sin become the ultimate basis for true kingdom allegiance. Practically, this commentary urges believers to examine their own desires for human authority versus Christ's kingship, ensuring that any leadership structures honor God's covenant promises without compromising spiritual accountability. It challenges modern communities to cultivate humility in leadership, maintain transparent accountability systems, and recognize that true freedom comes not from political power but from Christ's reconciling work—where the people's confession of Samuel's innocence mirrors the church's need to confess its dependence on Christ's witness rather than human systems. (248 words)

Samuel's testimony in 1 Samuel 12 reveals a pivotal moment where Israel's choice of a king confronts the divine covenant.
